columns.text: In this problem, we will calculate the EAR in a one-year loan of $10,000 with an interest rate of 12% plus three points, wherein one point refers to 1% of the loan amount. Additionally, we will identify if the EAR is affected by the loan amount.

We will consider in this calculation the following details from the problem:

| Particulars   |            |
|---------------|------------|
| Present value | $10,000 |
| Interest rate | 12%       |
| Period        | 1 (year)   |

First, we will identify the future value of the loan.

The future value represents the value of an amount at a future date after considering the present value multiplied by the rate and period factor.

The future value can be calculated using the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
FV &=PV\times\left(1 + r\right)^{t}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$FV$, which refers to future value\
$PV$, which means the present value\
$t$, which represent the period\
$r$, which indicate the discount rate

Next, we will identify the net amount received from the loan.

Considering the three points deducted outset of the loan, we will calculate the net amount received by subtracting the value points from the present value. If one point is equal to 1%, the value of the three-point to be deducted onset is 3%.

In calculating the net amount received from the loan, we can summarize our computation in the following equation:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Net Amount Received} &=\text{Loan's amount}\times\left(1 + \text{Percentage of points}\right)
\end{aligned}$$

Let's now determine the net amount received from the loan.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Net Amount Received} &=\$10,000\times\left(1 - 0.03\right)
\\[5pt]
&=\$10,000\times0.97
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\$9,700}
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, after considering the 3-point reduction, the net amount received from the loan is $9,700.

Considering the net amount received as the present value and the future value from the first calculation, we will determine the EAR of the loan. Hence, we will consider the following data:

| Particulars   |            |
|---------------|------------|
| Present value | $9,700 |
| Future value | $11,200       |
| Period        | 1 (year)   |

The EAR or *Effective Annual Rate* is the actual rate of return from a loan or an investment considering the compounding of periods. 

The effective annual rate is typically calculated by the nominal rate and compounding period factor. However, there is an onset three points reduction on the amount received; hence, we will use a spreadsheet function Rate to calculate the EAR.

Let's discuss what the rate function in the spreadsheet is.

The rate function in the spreadsheet is a financial function that calculates the rate of a loan considering the present value, future value, and the period of the loan.

The rate function can be used in the spreadsheet with the following syntax:

$$\begin{aligned}
RATE&=(nper,pmt,pv,[fv],[type]) \\
\end{aligned}$$


Where:

$nper$, which refers to the period\
$pmt$, which means the constant payment\
$pv$, which represent the present value\
$fv$, the future value\
$type$, which indicates the basis of the calculation, either year-end or beginning of the year

Let's now calculate the loan's effective annual rate using the rate function on the spreadsheet. Note that the present value should be negative for the function to work. 

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/264b37d0-1c53-436a-b863-ba2842b756fd-1643545168633998.png)

**Based on our calculation, the loan's effective annual rate considering the three points due onset is 15.46%.**

Finally, let's discuss if the loan amount affects the effective annual rate.

As explained in the previous steps, the effective annual rate is the real rate of return or paid in a loan, calculated usually by the factor of the nominal rate and compounding of the period. However, since the loan includes points initially deducted on the amount received, the points value became the primary factor that impacts the loan's effective annual rate.

As stated in the problem, the value of one point represents 1% of the loan amount. Since the points value rate is fixed and depends on the loan amount, supposed the loan amount is increased or decreased, the effective annual rate will remain the same since the present value, and the loan's future value will adjust accordingly.

**Therefore, the effective annual rate is not influenced by the loan's amount.**

To conclude, after considering the points subtracted from the amount received from the loan, the effective annual rate of the loan is 15.46%. The loan amount does not impact the rate since the value of the points always depends on the amount of the loan.
